Author: jl777c#5810

Author: jl777c#5810

Content: Electrum is less secure, in some situations, such as a chainfork

Author: kimmel (Pungo.io)#2275
Content: well electrum afak delegates the tx check and broadcast to a single node...if node is on a fork or its attacked yes u're fucked...and also the node could perform additional data-mining on people using it...

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: when there is a chainfork, the light wallet node follows whatever chain the server it happens to talk to is using, and that is randomized on startup in Electrum

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: some electrum clients have better randomization than others, some coins have only 1 or 2 servers

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: a full node is more safe in those situations. For BTC there are dozens of servers that use to randomly pick from, makes it a bit more secure

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: electrum servers also know your IP and if you are the fist to broadcast an xtn, like @kimmel (Pungo.io) says

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: newest electrum, which most coins don't have, has more protections

Author: kimmel (Pungo.io)#2275
Content: however electrum nodes can be protected to avoid 3rd party usage...or to accept only connection from certain ip's

Author: kimmel (Pungo.io)#2275
Content: thats especially effective when using the mobile proxy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yeah, please

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: maintaining electrum code and servers is horrific and painful

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you can't keep in sync with upstream because they make massive backward-compatible-breaking changes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: merging in features/bugfixes is not fun

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and every client gui and backend server is slightly different, since electrumx changes the world sometimes

Author: kimmel (Pungo.io)#2275
Content: right guess thats a good reason to avoid having open electrum hosts too

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you can trust the merkleroot at a height, then you can validate a txproof that a specific rawtx was in that block

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Yep thx found spec

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: THAT is the only trust that is needed in electrum

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so you can query N different sites for the merkle root of height X, make sure there is consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then you can verify that the rawtx indeed was in the block at the confidence level that not all the merkle roots were fake

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Ok so u need a bit more work on the client to be “safe” by querying more servers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so yes, it is less secure than a fullnode, but let us not go crazy about how insecure it is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: understand its weakness, which is that it needs to know the merkleroot of specific height

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can also just sync headers only via the p2p network and then be able to have confidence in the SPV

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i think what you describe could be implemented as a more secure/paranoid mode

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: same as a full node

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it would actually be useful in a chainfork (BTC vs BCH) kind of deal

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I think the best mix is to make a headers only full node, and then it does SPV validations for all tx

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then it wont need to get help from any external server

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think the breadwallet does this

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no need for electrum hosts using the headers sync SPV client

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: breadwallet connects to the actual p2p network

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a non-relaying peer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: syncs headers and thats it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe occasionally sends a transaction

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we assume it is scanning incoming blocks and tracking its own transactions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a coin has no full nodes, then it isnt a real coin

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let the mobile market run breadwallets

Author: kimmel (Pungo.io)#2275

Author: kimmel (Pungo.io)#2275
Content: I mean relying on a single node doesnt has to be bad...while you are aware of it and while you cross check the results on explorers

Author: jl777c#5810

Content: usually diversity of methods leads to a more resilient network

Author: kimmel (Pungo.io)#2275
